item.title: Jerusalem Is First Stop as Kerry Seeks Support of Allies
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry landed in Jerusalem for the first of a series of meetings with allies to assure support for the chemical weapons deal, and he said the threat of force was still in place.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, and Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel after a news conference Sunday in Jerusalem on the Syrian conflict.

item.title: Letter From Washington: Messaging Is Hurting Obama
item.description: At risk of being branded incompetent, President Obama may escape some collateral damage if the deal reached with the Russians holds and Syria relinquishes its chemical weapons.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: Gunmen Shoot Female Afghan Police Commander
item.description: Two gunmen on a motorcycle shot and wounded the police commander from behind, possibly paralyzing her. No one has claimed responsibility, but it was the third such attack on a female officer since July.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SHARIFULLAH SAHAK

item.title: Cambodia Police Use Water Cannons on Protesters
item.description: The demonstrators vowed to continue their push for an independent investigation of results from the July election.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Hails Syrian Pact, Calling It a Crucial Step
item.description: President Obama said the deal to destroy Syria’s chemical weapons would put Washington in a “better position” to prevent the government from using poison gas again.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: Afghanistan Mine Collapse Kills at Least 20
item.description: The government has ordered an investigation into the cause of the accident, which occurred Saturday afternoon in northern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and SHARIFULLAH SAHAK

item.title: The Lede: Sanctions on Iran Extend to YouTube
item.description: Iran’s state-owned channel Press TV has been engaged in a battle of wits with YouTube in recent months over whether access to the video-sharing site violates American sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Spain Bars Catalan Independence Vote
item.description: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy wrote that a separation would involve “enormous cost” to the country, and suggested talks with the Catalonian leader instead.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Campaign in Germany, an Influence Far Beyond It
item.description: Seeking a third term as chancellor, Angela Merkel is saying little about the future of Europe, while the rest of the world scours the election race for clues to her intentions.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: A campaign sign in Berlin for Angela Merkel. She is widely expected to win a third four-year term in elections that are scheduled for next Sunday.

item.title: Syrian Opposition Group Elects New Prime Minister
item.description: Ahmad Tomeh ran unopposed and was said to be a consensus candidate accepted by a secular-leaning coalition within the Syrian National Council.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: If History Is Any Measure, the Clock Is Ticking
item.description: Weapons experts and diplomats say that if President Bashar al-Assad is serious about giving up his arsenal, he will have to take dramatic action in the coming weeks.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM J. BROAD and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Workers under the supervision of United Nations inspectors in 1996 destroyed growth media that could be used to produce biological weapons in Iraq.

item.title: Russia Preparing Patrols of Arctic Shipping Lanes
item.description: The military said the regular patrols are meant to protect the thousands of miles of coastline suddenly open to other countries’ ships on a regular basis.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Reshaping Brazil’s Retail Scene, Inspired by Vegas and Vanderbilt
item.description: A department store tycoon takes unfettered American-style consumerism to a gaudy new level.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The flagship Havan store in Brusque, in Brazil’s south, draws shoppers with its low prices and novel style.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Reach Deal to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Arms
item.description: The announcement by Secretary of State John Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, set the stage for one of the most challenging undertakings in the history of arms control.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry and Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov of Russia, right, shook hands on Saturday after making statements following meetings regarding Syria in Geneva.

item.title: Philippine Leaders Descend on Strife-Torn City as Hopes of Cease-Fire Fade
item.description: Top Philippine leaders discussed strategies Saturday for dealing with violence that has killed at least 55 people, displaced more than 62,000 and crippled a once peaceful trading enclave.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY
item.media:description: Thousands of villagers were camped out at a stadium to flee the fighting between Philippine government forces and Muslim rebels on Saturday in Zamboanga City.

item.title: As Turmoil Persists, Mubarak Returns to Courtroom in Egypt
item.description: Hosni Mubarak, the former president of Egypt, returned to court in Cairo in the killings of about 900 protesters during the 2011 uprising.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Deadly Bombing Hits Iraqi Funeral
item.description: A suicide bomber is said to have killed at least 21 people at the funeral of a member of Iraq’s Shabak ethnic minority near Mosul.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Police Seize Weapons Shipment
item.description: The Croatian authorities say they have seized large quantities of illegal military equipment, including rocket launchers and antiaircraft rockets, found in a shipment from Serbia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Former C.I.A. Chief Requests Pardon for 2009 Rendition Conviction
item.description: A former C.I.A. station chief is seeking a pardon from Italy’s president for his 2009 kidnapping conviction in the “extraordinary rendition” of a Muslim cleric off the streets of Milan.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Leader Turns Against Rebels Who Put Him in Power
item.description: The rebel group that swept to power in March was dissolved by a decree issued by the very president it had installed, according to state radio.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Rebels Agree to Cease-Fire
item.description: The vice president of the Philippines, Jejomar Binay, said that a Muslim rebel leader had accepted a cease-fire to allow talks on ending a five-day hostage crisis.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Mideast: Iraq: At Least 33 Die in Fresh Spurt of Violence; Mosque Is Bombed
item.description: Attacks across Iraq, including a bombing at a Sunni mosque north of Baghdad, killed 33 people in the latest eruption of violence to rock the country, officials said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Coalition Governing Could Be Britain’s New Normal Despite Liberal Democrats’ Troubles
item.description: Before 2010, Britons had largely dismissed political alliances, like the Liberal Democrats’ coalition with the dominant Conservatives, as chaotic and messy.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Nick Clegg, the besieged leader of the Liberal Democrats.

item.title: Protest by Mexican Teachers Is Ended
item.description: The police moved to reclaim a historic square in Mexico City two days before the nation’s Independence Day celebration is to be held there.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Filmmaker Giving Voice to Acts of Rage in Today’s China
item.description: Reports of ordinary Chinese being driven to violence persuaded the director Jia Zhangke to put aside his first big-budget martial arts film and tell their story instead.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
